nodes.bodyText: Moved to https://github.com/jenkinsci/kubernetes-plugin/pull/772/files#diff-55ff61b56516ad2fa5dd36df80c3836cR243
Moved to PodUtils
Moved to https://github.com/jenkinsci/kubernetes-plugin/pull/772/files#diff-55ff61b56516ad2fa5dd36df80c3836cR243
Fixed null handling
Moved to https://github.com/jenkinsci/kubernetes-plugin/pull/772/files#diff-55ff61b56516ad2fa5dd36df80c3836cR195
https://github.com/jenkinsci/kubernetes-plugin/pull/772/files#diff-55ff61b56516ad2fa5dd36df80c3836cR213 intercepts the event before the node is actually removed.
Mm, so making this test not exactly useless but not testing the original fix. OK.
I was able to restore the behaviour by not interrupting the executors in the new listeners.

or

                            .filter(n -> n instanceof KubernetesSlave)

just to show off Java 8 skills without really making code more legible
(plus s/extends/implements/g below of course)
Better for the caller at https://github.com/jenkinsci/kubernetes-plugin/pull/772/files#diff-55ff61b56516ad2fa5dd36df80c3836cR155 to catch Exception for any listener
Nice!
What will this test do if run in a cluster with PodSecurityPolicy enabled?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@
+podTemplate(yaml:'''
+spec:
+  containers:
+  - name: jnlp
+    image: jenkins/inbound-agent:4.3-4 # alpine flavor has alpine 3.9 which doesn't have stress-ng
+    securityContext:
+      runAsUser: 0
+      privileged: true

nodes.bodyText: Probably timeout since the pod won't be scheduled.

nodes.bodyText: Maybe better to just publish an image (e.g., Docker Hub automated build) with this preinstalled? Or kill a different container using an image that already has this tool installed? Or perhaps there is some stock Linux command which can be forced to do giant allocations with the right arguments?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,22 @@
+podTemplate(yaml:'''
+spec:
+  containers:
+  - name: jnlp
+    image: jenkins/inbound-agent:4.3-4 # alpine flavor has alpine 3.9 which doesn't have stress-ng
+    securityContext:
+      runAsUser: 0
+      privileged: true
+    resources:
+      limits:
+        memory: "256Mi"
+      requests:
+        memory: "256Mi"
+''') {
+  node(POD_LABEL) {
+    sh '''
+        apt-get update
+        apt-get install -y stress-ng

nodes.bodyText: Yes, didn't want to go through the route of publishing a new docker image just for that purpose. I know @Dohbedoh had one set up but ideally I'd avoid depending on third party.
